input:
2. A 9-year-old male is brought to the clinic due to gradually worsening gait instability and frequent falls over the last six months. His parents also note difficulty with eye movements, complaining of double vision and trouble focusing. On examination, he demonstrates spastic paraparesis, brisk reflexes, and mild limb ataxia, along with horizontal nystagmus. Brain and spinal cord MRI reveal widespread signal abnormalities in the cerebral white matter, brainstem, and dorsal columns of the spinal cord, with magnetic resonance spectroscopy indicating elevated lactate levels. Blood lactate is also elevated at rest, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis is normal aside from lactate elevation. There is no significant family history, and infectious and inflammatory causes have been excluded. Genetic sequencing identifies pathogenic variants in the DARS2 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Leukoencephalopathy with Brainstem and Spinal Cord Involvement and Lactate Elevation (LBSL). The patient is referred for multidisciplinary management including neurology, physical therapy, and genetic counseling.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: Since the patient is a child, but I need to answer as a caregiver or the child himself, I should keep it simple and focused on what has been going on lately. The main concern is the worsening of movement problems and eye issues over time. It's important to mention the recent progression and that he's been falling more often.

ANSWER: I’m 9 years old and I’m a boy. I’ve been falling more and more and I have trouble walking straight, especially when I try to run or play. My eyes bother me too; I see things double and it’s hard to focus.

input: 2. A 9-year-old male is brought to the clinic due to gradually worsening gait instability and frequent falls over the last six months. There is no significant family history, and infectious and inflammatory causes have been excluded. Genetic sequencing identifies pathogenic variants in the DARS2 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Leukoencephalopathy with Brainstem and Spinal Cord Involvement and Lactate Elevation (LBSL). The patient is referred for multidisciplinary management including neurology, physical therapy, and genetic counseling.Can you tell me more about when these problems started, how they have changed over time, and if you have noticed anything else about how you're feeling or behaving?
output: Um, I think it’s been getting worse little by little for a few months now. I’ve been falling more and it’s harder to keep my balance. Usually I get double vision sometimes and I feel kinda of out of it sometimes, like I don’t see straight. I don’t know if I’m acting differently or anything, but I just feel kind of weird a lot.

input: 2. A 9-year-old male is brought to the clinic due to gradually worsening gait instability and frequent falls over the last six months. There is no significant family history, and infectious and inflammatory causes have been excluded. Genetic sequencing identifies pathogenic variants in the DARS2 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Leukoencephalopathy with Brainstem and Spinal Cord Involvement and Lactate Elevation (LBSL). The patient is referred for multidisciplinary management including neurology, physical therapy, and genetic counseling.Can you tell me more about what happens when you try to run or play—how do your symptoms affect your movements, and what else do you notice when you’re feeling "out of it" or having double vision?
output: When I try to run or play, it’s like my legs aren’t really working right. I feel really wobbly, and sometimes I fall down even if I don’t mean to. When I get double vision, everything looks like it’s split in two or kinda blurry, and it’s hard to focus on stuff. I don’t always know when I’ll feel like that, but it makes me nervous.

input: 2. A 9-year-old male is brought to the clinic due to gradually worsening gait instability and frequent falls over the last six months. The patient is referred for multidisciplinary management including neurology, physical therapy, and genetic counseling.Can you describe how your child's symptoms affect his daily activities, such as playing, school, or other routines, and if you've noticed anything that seems to make his symptoms better or worse?
output: Well, he’s been falling more than before, even just while trying to walk around the house or play outside. Sometimes he gets really tired and doesn’t want to do much, and he seems almost confused or distracted a lot. We haven’t really noticed anything that helps or makes it worse, honestly — it just seems to be getting worse gradually.

output: Um, I think he had a cold maybe a little while ago, but I'm not really sure if it was recent... it's all been kind of blurry with everything else going on.

output: No, he hasn't had any seizures or sudden weakness or speech problems that I saw. But sometimes he really gets tired or kind of struggles more with moving his legs, and I worry about that.

input: 2. A 9-year-old male is brought to the clinic due to gradually worsening gait instability and frequent falls over the last six months. The patient is referred for multidisciplinary management including neurology, physical therapy, and genetic counseling.Has your child experienced any episodes of headaches, vomiting, or neck stiffness? Have these "out of it" moments or visual disturbances been associated with any specific activities, times of day, or recent illnesses?
output: Um, he’s never had really bad headaches or throwing up that I remember, and he doesn’t seem stiff or different in his neck that way. Sometimes, he does look kind of out of it, like he's staring or confused, but I don’t know if it’s related to anything particular. It happens randomly, and I don’t think it’s after eating or anything like that. And his eyes being weird — it just kind of happens randomly too.

output: I don’t really know if there’s a certain time or thing that makes it worse. Sometimes I feel funny after I play or when I’m tired, but I can’t tell if that’s the same thing or just me being tired. I don’t remember any head bumps or anything like that.

output: Um, yeah, he's been having some headaches, but I think they come and go. Sometimes he seems really tired or tried to fall asleep more easily, even during the day. I’m not sure if it's, like, things getting worse or just normal tiredness.

The patient is referred for multidisciplinary management including neurology, physical therapy, and genetic counseling.Has your child noticed if his double or blurry vision worsens after exercising, during periods of fatigue, or if it improves with rest?
output: Um, sometimes his eyes feel weird, like things look double or blurry, and I guess it gets worse when he’s been running around or tired, but then if he rests a little, it’s a bit better. I’m not really sure if it always changes—sometimes it just stays the same.
